title: Drug Discovery & Molecular Simulation
shortDescription: Simulate molecular interactions to accelerate pharmaceutical research and reduce drug development costs
fullDescription: Quantum computers can simulate molecular and chemical interactions at a level of detail impossible for classical computers. This enables pharmaceutical companies to model drug-protein interactions, predict drug efficacy, and identify promising candidates much faster than traditional methods. Current classical simulations are limited to small molecules due to computational complexity that grows exponentially with molecule size.
quantumAdvantage: Quantum systems naturally model quantum mechanical behavior of molecules. Classical computers must approximate these interactions, requiring exponential resources as molecule size grows. Quantum advantage appears for molecules with >50 atoms.

timeline.current: IBM, Google, and pharma companies running proof-of-concept simulations on small molecules (5-10 atoms)
timeline.nearTerm: 1-3 years: Simulations of drug-like molecules (20-30 atoms) with error mitigation
timeline.longTerm: 5+ years: Full protein-drug interaction simulations with fault-tolerant quantum computers

title: Financial Portfolio Optimization
shortDescription: Optimize investment portfolios with complex constraints to maximize returns while minimizing risk
fullDescription: Portfolio optimization involves selecting the best combination of assets to maximize expected returns while minimizing risk, subject to numerous constraints (regulatory, liquidity, sector limits). This becomes exponentially complex with more assets and constraints. Quantum algorithms like QAOA (Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm) can explore solution spaces more efficiently than classical methods.
quantumAdvantage: Classical portfolio optimization struggles with >1000 assets and complex constraints. Quantum algorithms can evaluate exponentially more portfolio combinations simultaneously through superposition, potentially finding better solutions faster.

timeline.current: Major banks (JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs) testing quantum algorithms on small portfolios (50-100 assets)
timeline.nearTerm: 1-3 years: Production pilots for mid-size portfolios (500+ assets) with hybrid quantum-classical approaches
timeline.longTerm: 5+ years: Real-time optimization of large institutional portfolios with thousands of assets

title: Supply Chain & Logistics Optimization
shortDescription: Optimize complex routing, scheduling, and inventory decisions across global supply networks
fullDescription: Modern supply chains involve thousands of variables: routing decisions, inventory levels, production schedules, shipping constraints, and demand forecasts. Finding optimal solutions is NP-hard and becomes intractable for classical computers as the network grows. Quantum optimization algorithms can explore solution spaces more efficiently, potentially saving millions in logistics costs.
quantumAdvantage: Routing problems grow exponentially with network size (traveling salesman problem). Quantum algorithms like QAOA and quantum annealing can explore multiple routes simultaneously, potentially finding near-optimal solutions faster for large networks (>1000 nodes).

timeline.current: DHL, Volkswagen, and others running small-scale proofs-of-concept (10-50 nodes)
timeline.nearTerm: 1-3 years: Pilot deployments for regional supply chains (100-500 nodes)
timeline.longTerm: 5+ years: Global supply chain optimization in real-time

title: Advanced Materials Discovery
shortDescription: Discover new materials with specific properties for batteries, superconductors, and industrial applications
fullDescription: Designing new materials (superconductors, catalysts, battery materials) requires understanding quantum mechanical properties and interactions. Classical simulations are limited to simple structures. Quantum computers can simulate material properties at the atomic level, accelerating discovery of materials with desired characteristics like higher energy density, better conductivity, or specific optical properties.
quantumAdvantage: Material properties emerge from quantum interactions between atoms. Classical methods use approximations that break down for strongly correlated systems. Quantum simulation provides accurate predictions for materials where classical methods fail, potentially discovering materials years faster.

timeline.current: Research labs simulating simple crystal structures and chemical bonds
timeline.nearTerm: 1-3 years: Predict properties of candidate materials for batteries and catalysts
timeline.longTerm: 5+ years: Design custom materials with specific properties on-demand

title: Post-Quantum Cryptography
shortDescription: Develop encryption methods resistant to quantum computer attacks to secure future communications
fullDescription: Today's encryption (RSA, ECC) relies on the computational difficulty of factoring large numbers or solving discrete logarithm problems. Quantum computers running Shor's algorithm can break these in polynomial time, threatening all current encrypted communications. Post-quantum cryptography develops new encryption schemes based on mathematical problems that remain hard even for quantum computers (lattice-based, hash-based, code-based cryptography).
quantumAdvantage: This is actually a quantum threat, not advantage. Quantum computers will break current encryption. The advantage is in developing quantum-resistant algorithms now, before large-scale quantum computers exist. NIST has already standardized several post-quantum algorithms.

timeline.current: NIST has standardized 4 post-quantum algorithms (CRYSTALS-Kyber, CRYSTALS-Dilithium, FALCON, SPHINCS+)
timeline.nearTerm: 1-3 years: Major tech companies migrating to post-quantum encryption
timeline.longTerm: 5+ years: Complete transition of internet infrastructure to quantum-resistant encryption

title: Quantum Machine Learning
shortDescription: Enhance machine learning models with quantum algorithms for pattern recognition and classification
fullDescription: Quantum machine learning explores quantum algorithms for tasks like classification, clustering, and pattern recognition. Quantum computers might process high-dimensional data more efficiently through quantum feature spaces. Applications include image recognition, fraud detection, and recommendation systems. The field is still theoretical with active research on where quantum advantage might emerge.
quantumAdvantage: Quantum algorithms may provide speedups for specific ML tasks like kernel methods, where data is mapped to high-dimensional quantum feature spaces. Advantage is unproven for general ML tasks. Most current 'quantum ML' experiments show no speedup over classical methods.

timeline.current: Academic research on quantum ML algorithms; no practical advantage demonstrated
timeline.nearTerm: 1-3 years: Identify specific ML tasks where quantum advantage might appear
timeline.longTerm: 5+ years: Possible quantum-enhanced ML for specific applications if advantage is proven

title: Traffic Flow & Urban Mobility Optimization
shortDescription: Optimize traffic light timing and routing to reduce congestion in smart cities
fullDescription: Urban traffic management involves coordinating thousands of traffic lights, predicting traffic patterns, and optimizing routing in real-time. The problem space grows exponentially with city size. Quantum optimization algorithms can evaluate multiple traffic scenarios simultaneously, potentially reducing congestion, emissions, and commute times. Applications extend to autonomous vehicle coordination and public transit scheduling.
quantumAdvantage: Traffic optimization is a combinatorial problem with exponential solution space. Quantum algorithms can explore multiple timing and routing combinations in parallel, potentially finding better solutions faster than classical heuristics for networks with >1000 intersections.

timeline.current: City pilots (Lisbon, Beijing) testing quantum algorithms on limited road networks
timeline.nearTerm: 1-3 years: Smart city deployments for traffic signal optimization in real-time
timeline.longTerm: 5+ years: Coordinated autonomous vehicle routing across entire metropolitan areas

title: Climate & Weather Modeling
shortDescription: Improve climate predictions by simulating complex atmospheric and ocean interactions
fullDescription: Climate modeling requires simulating interactions between atmosphere, oceans, ice sheets, and ecosystems at multiple scales. Current models make approximations due to computational limits. Quantum computers could simulate molecular-level processes (cloud formation, chemical reactions in atmosphere) that affect macro-scale climate, improving prediction accuracy for weather, hurricanes, and long-term climate change.
quantumAdvantage: Climate involves quantum processes (molecular reactions, energy transfer) and chaotic dynamics. Quantum simulation could model these processes accurately without classical approximations. Advantage expected for micro-scale processes that aggregate to macro effects, but requires fault-tolerant quantum computers.

timeline.current: Early research on quantum algorithms for fluid dynamics and chemical reactions
timeline.nearTerm: 1-3 years: Small-scale quantum simulations of atmospheric chemistry
timeline.longTerm: 5+ years: Quantum-enhanced climate models integrated with classical supercomputers

title: Financial Risk Analysis & Monte Carlo Simulation
shortDescription: Accelerate risk calculations using quantum amplitude estimation for faster Monte Carlo simulations
fullDescription: Financial institutions use Monte Carlo simulations to estimate risk, price derivatives, and stress-test portfolios. These simulations require thousands of random samples, making them computationally expensive. Quantum amplitude estimation (QAE) can provide quadratic speedup over classical Monte Carlo methods, potentially calculating risk metrics 100x faster for the same accuracy.
quantumAdvantage: Classical Monte Carlo requires O(1/ε²) samples for accuracy ε. Quantum amplitude estimation achieves O(1/ε) scaling, providing quadratic speedup. For complex derivatives and large portfolios, this could reduce calculation time from hours to minutes.

timeline.current: Banks testing quantum Monte Carlo algorithms on small option portfolios
timeline.nearTerm: 1-3 years: Hybrid quantum-classical risk engines for derivatives pricing
timeline.longTerm: 5+ years: Real-time risk calculation for entire trading books

title: Protein Folding Prediction
shortDescription: Predict 3D protein structures to understand diseases and design targeted therapies
fullDescription: Proteins fold into complex 3D shapes that determine their function. Predicting how a protein will fold from its amino acid sequence is critical for understanding diseases and designing drugs. Classical methods (like AlphaFold) use machine learning on known structures, but quantum simulation could predict folding for novel proteins by directly simulating quantum interactions between atoms, potentially revealing new therapeutic targets.
quantumAdvantage: Protein folding involves quantum mechanical interactions between atoms. Classical ML models learn patterns from existing data but cannot simulate the underlying physics. Quantum computers could simulate the folding process directly, potentially predicting structures for proteins unlike any in training data.

timeline.current: Early research on quantum algorithms for small peptide chains (5-10 amino acids)
timeline.nearTerm: 1-3 years: Quantum simulation of protein fragments to validate approaches
timeline.longTerm: 5+ years: Full protein folding simulation competing with classical ML methods
